Award.AwardTitle: Red Algae: A New Model for the Evolution of Parasitism
Award.AbstractNarration:
Parasitic organisms have independently evolved in every major lineage of life on Earth, however we know very little about the transition from free-living to parasite. Red algal parasites are ideal model organisms for investigating the origins of a parasitic life-strategy because most red algal parasites share an immediate common ancestor with a free-living red algal species. Therefore, a single pair of organisms can provide direct comparative data on the genetic changes occurring early in the evolution of a parasite. This project will characterize the co-evolutionary relationship from three species pairs of hosts and their parasites, then establish the effect of a parasitic strategy on their genomes

This study will provide information relevant to dealing with some of the most damaging eukaryotic pathogens and parasites (e.g. , the causes of malaria, toxoplasmosis, sudden oak death, and the Irish Potato Famine). Additionally, red algae are important players in marine and freshwater habitats throughout the world and are among the dominant members of the benthic coastal community. This study will involve the training of undergraduates, a graduate student, and a postdoctoral fellow. URI's highly successful NSF-sponsored Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program will be used to recruit undergraduate and graduate researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Parasitism as a life strategy has independently evolved numerous times throughout the tree-of-life. Most well studied parasites including Plasmodium (malaria), Toxoplasma (toxoplasmosis), and Phytophthora (Irish potato famine) last shared a common ancestor with a free-living relative hundreds of millions of years ago. Research into these parasites has uncovered the impacts of long-established parasitism, but how an organism adopts parasitism in the first place remains largely unknown. This project examined the evolutionary patterns during the early stages of an organisms’ transition from a free-living to a parasitic life strategy.

 

Red algae provide a unique system to study early parasite evolution because parasitic red algae infect free-living photosynthetic relatives and therefore share a recent common ancestor with their hosts. Furthermore, these patterns of parasite evolution occur in several independent red algal lineages. Because of the close relationship between photosynthetic and parasitic red algae, direct comparisons can be made with differences being attributable to their contrasting life strategies.

 

This project focused on genomic and transcriptomic differences between red algal parasites and their free-living hosts. Specimens were collected from the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of North America and their DNA and RNA was extracted and sequenced for subsequent comparative analyses. In total, this project generated data for nine parasitic and six free-living red algae. Mitochondrial and plastid genomes were completely sequenced from the parasite Choreocolax polysiphoniae and its host Vertebrata lanosa. The organellar genomes are partially complete for the parasites Harveyella mirabilis, Leachiella pacifica; Gonimophyllum skottsbergii, Janczewskia gardneri, and a previously undescribed parasite of Rhodomela sp. Transcriptomes were generated from the parasite-host pairs Vertebrata lanosa-Choreocolax polysiphoniae, Cryptopleura crispa-Gonimophyllum skottsbergii, Asterocolax gardneri-Polyneura latissima, and Asterocolax sp.-Phycodrys rubens. Both transcriptomes and nuclear genomes for the parasite Gracilariphila oryzoides and its host Gracilariopsis andersonii were assembled. The data collected for this study is the first fine-scale genomic comparison of a closely related parasite and its photosynthetic host and added significantly to the available data.

 

From the organellar genome data collected during this study, we demonstrated that the alloparasite Choreocolax polysiphoniae maintains its own unique plastid. The presence of this plastid challenges the cannonical hypothesis on red algal parasite evolution. The transcriptomes collected as part of this study has allowed for a single pair of organisms to provide comparative data on the genomic changes occurring early in the evolution of parasitism. In both datasets, the metabolic pathways involved with photosynthesis in the parasite are heavily impacted when compared to their hosts. Additionally there is a reduced set of plastid-targeted genes.

 

Until recently we were dependent upon field collection for our material. Each collection must undergo extensive antibiotic treatments to reduce contaminants. The development of stable culturing methods has changed how we collect material. We are now able to collect and isolate pure parasite spores using a modified hanging drop method. Thousands of isolated spores are then used to selectively re-infect host tissue. The development of culturing methods allows us to control the life cycle of the parasite, control the timing of infection, and follow the subsequent development of the infection.

 

Our ability to visualize the contents of cells has been significantly advanced by fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) methods. We have recently begun to develop a method for FISH in red algal tissue sections. DNA probes have been designed to target the mitochondria of Gracilariophila oryzoides and Gracilariopsis andersonii, which will allow us to follow the movement of organelles throughout development. Probe design is based on the transcriptomic and genomic data collected for this project and will target DNA and RNA sequences of interest. The implementation of FISH on red algal parasites and their hosts will be used to explore the impacts of cytoplasmic structure, intracellular communication and organellar control.

 

 

As part of the broader impacts of this project 1) future nine STEM researchers were trained; 2) a broader audience was exposed to scientific research; and 3) resources were generated for the scientific community. Throughout this project six undergraduates, two graduate students, and one post-doc were trained. We are continuing our commitment to supporting women and minorities in marine science as a graduate student member of the lab has founded and manages the University of Rhode Island chapter of the Society for Women in Marine Science (SWMS). Public outreach events included a Women in Science Day at Mystic Aquarium and a Science and Math Investigative Learning Experience (SMILE) event for local fourth graders. An algal diversity workshop was also developed and given at a local high school (22 students, South Kingston, RI) and for the Maritime Studies Program at Mystic Seaport (17 students).
